hawaiian_text: A hala ‘o Puali‘i i ka lawai‘a, i ia wā ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i hele ai me nā keiki he ‘umi  kumamāhiku i nā māla ‘uala a Puali‘i. ‘O ke kino o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ia wā, he kino ‘u‘uku loa, ‘elua  kapua‘i me ka hapa kona ki‘eki‘e, ‘a‘ole i pa‘a kona  ma‘i, e lewalewa ana nō. A hiki lākou i ua māla  ‘uala, kēnā akula ia i nā keiki, “E huhuki i ka pu‘e  me ka lau ‘uala ā pau loa i luna, mai waiho i kekahi e ulu ana.” Akā, maka‘u nō ua keiki, no laila, kāohi  mālie nō ma ka ‘uala, ‘a‘ohe huhuki i ka pu‘e.
qwen3-235b-a22b-exp-no_think-fireworks_t: "And Puali‘i went off fishing. At that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o went with ten young boys to Puali‘i's sweet potato patches. Nāmakaokapāo‘o at this time was very small, only two spans and a half of height, his body thin, not yet sturdy. Upon arriving at the sweet potato patches, he called out to the boys, 'Uproot the mounds entirely along with the vines on top, leaving none to grow again.' But the boys were fearful, so they only superficially heaped up the sweet potatoes without actually uprooting the mounds."

**Paragraph 5:**

• This paragraph continues to establish the early deeds of **Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o** (the eyes of the pāo‘o fish), detailing an incident at Puali‘i's sweet potato patches and illustrating the young boy's precocious character as well as the dynamic between him and other children around him. His leadership and confidence are starkly at odds with his physically diminutive stature.

• **Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s physique described** with the phrase *he kino ‘u‘uku loa*—a "very small body", *‘elua kapua‘i me ka hapa*— "two spans and a half" in height (approximately 3.5 feet or so, using the traditional Hawaiian unit of measurement: a span is roughly 9 inches), and *‘a‘ole i pa‘a kona ma‘i*—his thighs were not yet strong or firm. This emphasizes the paradox of a physically small boy who nonetheless exudes strength, confidence, and supernatural energy.

– This motif of a small, seemingly unimposing figure who is in fact extraordinarily strong appears in multiple traditions across Polynesia, including the stories of Pele, Kamapuaʻa, and Māui. In kanaka maoli cosmology, smallness of form often symbolizes great mana (spiritual power) or ʻaumakua-like qualities—power that works from beneath the surface, subtly and decisively.

• The **group of ten young boys (he ‘umi kumamāhiku)** accompanies Nāmakaokapāo‘o to the patches, suggesting that even at this young age, he is a leader among his peers. The number ten may hold symbolic or ritual meaning—ten is known as a sacred number in Polynesian traditions, often associated with completeness or a ceremonial quorum (e.g., in chants, offerings, or trials).

• Upon arrival at the patches, **Nāmakaokapāo‘o commands the boys**: *E huhuki i ka pu‘e me ka lau ‘uala ā pau loa i luna, mai waiho i kekahi e ulu ana*—"Uproot the heaps along with the sweet potato leaves completely from above, leaving none to grow again."  

– Huhuki is a powerful verb meaning to uproot, tear out, or destroy. It is often used in kānāwai (Hawaiian law), hula, and mo‘olelo to indicate forceful, symbolic destruction or transformation. The act of uprooting could be symbolic of overturning an old order—possibly a metaphor for the future dismantling of the ‘Ai Kapu system and the birth of a new socio-religious paradigm.

– The command includes *mai waiho i kekahi e ulu ana*—"do not leave one to grow again"—a phrase that intensifies the seriousness and finality of the act, and might symbolize a cleansing of the spiritually corrupt or oppressive practices of the past. We see this again in Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s future battles with Kānemilohā and other guardians of the old ways.

• In contrast to Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s clear directive, the **ten boys are described as makāhelehele** (nervous, fearful)—conforming to expected behavior under the strict social norms of the *ʻAi Kapu* era, where even speaking out of turn could bring dire consequences. Consequently, *kāohi mālie nō ma ka ʻuala*—"they only superficially heaped up the sweet potatoes"—without actually carrying out the full command.

– This echoes larger cultural tensions between those who strictly adhered to ancient kapu and those who, often through divine or semi-divine right, challenged or defied those restrictions. Nāmakaokapāo‘o may be portrayed as a force of kālai kapu (breaker of kapu), whether literally or symbolically.

– The narrative seems to associate Nāmakaokapāo‘o with kālai kapu themes, especially in later episodes. Here, in this early phase, he is issuing commands that challenge the integrity of someone else’s property (Pualiʻi, who at other points appears antagonistic), a sort of proto-sacrilege that may foreshadow deeper ritual actions later on.

• Given that **Puali‘i is likely Nā’malama’s descendant of a priestly or chiefly line**, his sweet potato patches symbolically link to land stewardship, spiritual duty, and potentially mana transfer. That a child—albeit a powerful one—commands their destruction could be a metaphor for cosmological change or ritual reordering by those deemed supernaturally sanctioned.

– Sweet potato (ʻuala) was a prime food in Hawaiian cosmology, associated with fertility, sustenance, and the land's mana. Its connection to the god Lono is especially strong (as in the Makahiki cycle), and disturbing it may have ritualistic significance—especially if it serves as a symbol of an old kapu order being disrupted.

**Name Etymologies:**

• **Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o** — "The eyes of the pāo'o (longtail fish)"  
  – The use of *pāoʻo* may symbolically invoke sharpness, slenderness, and stealth—qualities often ascribed to the fish and which transfer metaphorically to the character's physical build and character traits. It also evokes the pāoʻo of the gods, such as the hook used in the fishing up of lands, possibly linking Nāmakaokapāo‘o to ancestral oceanic mythologies.

  – The suffix *-ka-pāo‘o* may also linguistically echo *-ka-poʻo* (head, chief), subtly linking him to leadership and suggesting that his “eyes” are those of insight and vision—perhaps a prophet-like figure.

• **Puali‘i** — "Perhaps “floating like a moʻo,” or “desirous of land,” from *pua* (blossom, fragment) and *li‘i* (small) — indicating a younger male of influence, possibly a petty chief or priest. In some narratives, he represents the kahiko (ancient) world of old ways—especially as a foil to Nāmakaokapāo‘o. His role in these passages aligns with characters who resist change or hold tightly to authority rooted in kapu and lineage.

• **Tentative Allegorical Interpretation:**

– This passage can be interpreted allegorically as a symbolic disruption of the kapu system. The patches symbolize entrenched traditions—sacred food resources maintained by the male priesthood. Nāmakaokapāo‘o, possibly representing a new order or divine force, seeks a complete rupture, while the ten boys, who are not yet divinely appointed, stand as representatives of society—hesitant and fearful of breaking the established order.

– Given that this chapter is early in the narrative, it may foreshadow larger spiritual confrontations and the eventual transformation of Hawaiian cosmological thought that Nāmakaokapāoʻo is understood to have catalyzed.

reference_translation: When Puali‘i left to go fishing, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  came with seventeen other children to the sweet  potato patches of Puali‘i. The body of   Nāmakaokapāo‘o at the time was very small, just  two and a half feet tall. His penis was not yet fully  grown and was dangling. When the kids got to the   sweet potato patches, Nāmakaokapāo‘o told the  other kids, “Rip out all of the sweet potato leaves. Don’t leave anything growing.” The children were  afraid and hesitated when they reached the  tubers, and they did not pull those out of the  mound.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 5:**• While Pua-li‘i was away fishing, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  came with 17 other children (perhaps all boys) to the  2 sweet potato patches. The reason they came to the  patches is not stated immediately, but it appears the  reason was to play. The 17 friends of Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o seem to represent the Hawaiian people as a  whole (or perhaps a group of individuals the  storyteller thinks poorly of) allegorically and Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o seems to represent a progressive minded Hawaiian.  • Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o is described at this point of the  story as very small, perhaps 2 feet tall, and that his  penis was not yet fully grown and dangling, likely  meaning he was not wearing a malo.  – The lack of a malo on a boy is descriptive of the  child being too young to wear one. In ‘Ai Kapu  culture, when boys are deemed to be physically  able for chores and work to help sustain the family,  they would go through rites to thrust them into an  age of productive work to help support the family  demonstrated by wearing a malo on a daily basis. It  was a sign of maturity (footnote: Pukui, Haertig, Lee (1972:114) “For the *keiki lewalewa*—usually shortened to *lewalewa*—was yet a “dangler.” A small boy, so young his penis dangled. As a dangler, he wore no  *malo* (loincloth) and he lived and ate with the women. For he was yet *poke‘o*, too young to join the men. ¶ When the little dangler became six or seven years old, his status  changed in one decisive ceremony. This was the *kā i mua*...”);  • The description of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o as a pre malo-wearing child contradicts the maturity and  leadership he demonstrates by his actions and  cognitive skills, where he tells his friends to destroy  the garden. The children demonstrate hesitancy and  destroy the vines and leaves of the sweet potatoes,  but do not dig out the tubers from under the ground. – This likely demonstrates a social rhetorical   commentary about or critique of the ‘Ai Kapu  culture as a whole, that it was worthy of   destruction, with its segregation of men and  women and emphasis on heirarchy, perhaps a  justification for abandoning the culture in 1819\.  The hesitancy of the children, and their depiction in this story as indecisive and timid could be a   Protestant Christian bias (post-1820). The idea of  not pulling out the sweet potato tubers from the  ground could represent not entirely eliminating the  Hawaiian people/culture in the Christian era (not a  complete genocide) despite the biases against the  ‘Ai Kapu;
